Problem:
Consider a system governed by the linear operator equation \\(Lx = \lambda x\\). Analyze how utilizing a transformation \\(T(x) = e^{i\theta}x\\), where \\(i\\) is the imaginary unit and \\(\theta\\) a constant, affects the system over a time-scale \\(t\\).

If at a certain time \\(t_1\\), a new function \\(S(x) = e^{i\phi}x\\) (where \\(i\\) is the imaginary unit and \\(\phi\\) another constant) is applied as an intervention, will the endpoint \\(x(T)\\) for T > t_1 depend only on \\(Lx = \lambda x\\) and not on \\(\theta\\) or \\(\phi\\)?
Explanation: Both interventions, \\(T\\) and \\(S\\), simply introduce a phase shift without altering the dynamics governed by L. Hence, the endpoint \\(x(T)\\) depends solely on the scaling factor \\(e^{\lambda T}\\) determined by L, despite the phase shifts introduced by \\(\theta\\) and \\(\phi\\).
